results.title: First Hand: five films
results.brief_description:
First Hand is a Koorie Heritage Trust cultural training and media project for young Indigenous people in Melbourne and regional areas. The project gives young Koories the skills to explore questions of culture and identity through the moving image.
During late 2004 and early 2005, participants completed training in communications, media and cultural studies, practical workshops in video production and a scriptwriting workshop held in the Screen Pit at ACMI. Community elders from metropolitan and regional areas (including Uncle Wally Cooper, Aunty Joy Wandin-Murphy and Uncle Sandy Atkinson) facilitated discussions about Indigenous culture and identity.

results.title: Possum's tale
results.brief_description:
“My country is in my heart everywhere I go. My country is in my blood no matter what happens to me. My country is my family and my community…”
This is a poetic documentary exploring the spiritual connection between Aboriginal people and the country they were born in. It recreates the childhood experience of the director, Josie Atkinson, as she attempts to return home to her country as a young child.

results.title: Old man: returning to Lake Condah Mission
results.brief_description: This is a documentary film about growing up on Lake Condah Aboriginal Mission. A local Elder, Uncle Kenny Saunders, visits the site of Lake Condah Mission and talks about his childhood memories revealing a past of cruelty and fear, and the devastation felt in the aftermath of the Eumerella massacres.

results.title: No dedication (no education)
results.brief_description: This film is part documentary and part music video. On Sunday 17th April 2005, Johnny Mac, a Koorie MC from Melbourne, performed at an outdoor concert and BBQ for 40 odd kids and their parents at the Ballarat Aboriginal Cooperative. The theme of the song and the day was education and the kids captured footage of the show and interviewed their parents and Elders about their school days.

results.title: Memories: a short walk with Aunty Maude
results.brief_description: This is a documentary film about the childhood and life of Aunty Maude Alberts, a Gundijimara Elder and the filmmaker’s grandmother. With her children and grandchildren Aunty Maude visits “the old place”, a property outside of Heywood where she grew up. The film makes a poetic exploration of Aunty Maude’s upbringing and the passing on of her traditional knowledge to her children and grandchildren.

results.title: In this situation again = In this place again
results.brief_description:
This is a documentary film about the friendship between an inmate at Bendigo Prison, Shane Lovett, and a young Koorie called Tim from Heywood. Tim visits Shane at the prison to talk about the music he has been making and what life is like in prison.
Music: “Barganji River Tribe” Shane Lovett and Sonny Wise; “Only Dreaming” Shane Lovett; “So Go” Shane Lovett

results.title: Sharpies [a gathering]
results.brief_description: Greg Mcainsh’s 1974 film ‘Sharpies’ documented a massive gathering of the Melbourne Sharpies at a Lobby Loyde concert. The final black and white short film is an exemplary cultural document of a time, a place and a powerful gathering of cultural resistance. This work uses the original footage and materials to present a silent exploration of the Sharpies at this particular moment in Melbourne’s history.

results.title: Sharpies [a documented history]
results.brief_description: Using Larry Jenkins’ extraordinary and comprehensive photographic archives of the Sharpies throughout the 1970s, this Public Imaging work is an edited collage of photographic materials and provides viewers with a rare insight into this counter cultural grouping. Faces, places, gatherings, gestures and fashion are explored through this rhythmic assemblage of images. The work consists of two sections: one consisting primarily of portraits and social groupings; the second concentrating on details of gestures and adornments representative of Sharpie culture.

results.title: Disappeared racecourses of north west Victoria
results.brief_description:
One of 6 works created in 2003 by community artist Malcolm McKinnon specifically for the MAP project. Each of the 6 works focuses on a different aspect of memory and identity in the Wimmera/Mallee region.
Ian Fisher was a champion jockey in north west Victoria in the 1930s and ‘40s. In this film he and his brother Trenfield recall the tracks they raced on across this region, most of which have now disappeared. Standing on the site of the old Rainbow racecourse, Ian tells the story of winning the Rainbow Cup in 1937 and remembers the people who “made racing” in that era.
